newsitem.title: IRAQ: More wheat lands in Iraq under oil deal with U.N..
newsitem.headline: More wheat lands in Iraq under oil deal with U.N..

text.p: A total of 66,402 tonnes of wheat have arrived in Iraq under its oil-for-food deal with the United Nations, a U.N. official said on Tuesday.
Eric Falt, spokesman for the U.N. humanitarian coordinator in Iraq, said the cargo ship Gunay carrying 29,162 tonnes of French wheat anchored at Umm Qasr late Monday night.
He said the cargo ship Virtue, carrying the first shipment of wheat from Australia, docked at the port earlier on Monday.
"Unloading operations have started immediately and dispatched to (Iraqi) governorates," Falt said.
The deal, which went into effect in December, allows Iraq, which is under U.N.-imposed sanctions, to sell oil worth $2 billion to buy food and medicine.
The first consignments of food arrived last week -- chickpeas, beans and vegetable oil on trucks from Turkey and Jordan. A shipload of 13,000 tonnes of rice has also reached the country.
"A total of 90,000 tonnes of food supplies have reached Iraq out of an anticipated 2,227,000 tonnes of food over six months," Falt added.
All these shipments are part of contracts approved by the U.N. sanctions committee on Iraq. Falt said the committee ratified a new contract for 2,800 tonnes of soap, expected to arrive from Jordan.
Baghdad said on Monday it would increase from April the monthly flour ration handed out to Iraqis. Rations of other commodities such as rice, sugar, pulses and tea would be raised from May.
A U.N. source confirmed Iraq's announcement saying "there is now an accelerated process in order to start distribution of flour".
